CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, September 20, 1969, pg. 1 reads: "The city's 'Black Monday' demonstration march in behalf of the Black Construction Coalition's Drive to gain construction jobs for blacks was led by BCC leaders and included an estimated 10,000 persons. Preparing to lead the two hour march from Centre and Crawford Ave. were from the left, Michael Dismond [Desmond], executive director, Bidwell Cultural & Training Center; the Rev. Jimmy Joe Robinson, the center's director; Nate Smith of Operation Dig, and Atty Byrd Brown, head of the local NAACP." Cutline for image also published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 6, 1976, pg. 1, reads: "Freedom Corner - Where are they now? Some of the leaders of the 1960s gather at Freedom Corner, Centre Avenue and Crawford Street, to begin a protest march downtown.  In front, left to right, were Mike Desmond, Rev. Jimmy Joe Robinson, Nate Smith and Byrd Brown.  In back were Aaron Mann, Lloyd Bell, Louis Boykins and an unidentified man in a white shirt. - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: "Black Monday" demonstration with Mike Desmond, Rev. Jimmy Joe Robinson, Nate Smith, and Byrd Brown in front, and others including Lloyd Bell, Dr. Norman Johnson, Aaron Mann, Louis Boykins, Vince "Roots" Wilson in light colored hat, police officer William "Mugsy "Moore, James "Swampman" Williams, and Matthew Moore in background, Freedom Corner, Lower Hill District
